Recognizing Neurodiversity in Girls By: Vicky Chen Editor: Julia Stepp “What’s wrong with me?” This is the haunting question millions of undiagnosed young girls with autism and ADHD grapple with. For years, their differences have been chalked up to laziness, disorganization or other personality defects, while their male counterparts are much more readily diagnosed and supported. Having been primarily studied in males, Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) were widely considered to be predominantly "male disorders" for decades. This male-centric view has led to countless women receiving late diagnoses, being misdiagnosed, or being missed entirely. While 10% of boys aged 12 to 17 are diagnosed with ADHD, only 2.7% of females in the same age group are similarly identified. Most boys are diagnosed by age 7, while girls are often not diagnosed until their 30s or 40s (Hinshaw & Scheffler, 2014). Similarly, autistic boys are three times more likely to get diagnosed than girls. Many women only get diagnosed after their children or siblings are assessed for ADHD and/or autism. Without a diagnosis, many women with ADHD and/or autism describe spending their lives feeling “confused,” “stupid,” or “lazy,” often blaming themselves for their perceived underachievement. For forty-nine-year-old Maggie, this confusion lasted decades; her ADHD traits were “dismissed as ‘hormones,’ anxiety, or simply being ‘a bit odd.’” She recalls that “[her] world was consumed with self-doubt, and [her] mind felt broken.”

For many women, a late diagnosis is a burden lifted. Anna, a 49-year-old ADHDer, describes her diagnosis at forty-five as “a huge relief,” explaining that she “immediately began to give [herself] grace for the things [she] found difficult.” Similarly, Julia, 16, reflects that she “no longer shames [herself] for being different from what society says is ‘normal,’” adding that if psychologists better understood how differently autism can present in girls, then “maybe we could skip the feelings of wrongness and shame.” Under an assumption of neurotypicality, girls and young women with ADHD and/or autism fly under the radar and lack early support strategies. They can experience “academic underachievement, unemployment, [and] relationship difficulties,” says Dr. Dawn K. Brown. The absence of healthy mechanisms in place may lead to maladaptive coping behaviours like “turning to recreational drugs, alcohol, nicotine, and sex to self-medicate” (ADDitude, 2023), leading to unplanned or teen pregnancies. Schechter adds that undiagnosed women face “higher rates of depression and anxiety, intimate partner victimization, and are significantly more likely to attempt suicide.” Given that diagnosis is so liberating and the consequences without it so dire, why are so many women undiagnosed? First, ADHD/autistic girls often employ “masking” to obscure their ADHD/autistic traits. This is paired with a lack of clinician training and experience in recognising the internal ADHD/autistic experience. Further, there are misleading stereotypes about how ADHD/autism is presented, in which the prevailing notion has been that girls and women don’t “get” ADHD or autism. They have therefore been habitually overlooked for diagnosis and study. Diagnostic criteria have historically downplayed female manifestations, focusing on overtly behavioral indicators and the externalised traits that are more common in males. Socially, parents and teachers may overlook girls as they don’t typically express the stereotyped manifestation of ADHD/autism. As diagnosis is based on how these figures interpret a child’s behaviour, these biases can deeply affect accurate diagnosis. One recent study found implicit bias among educators, where they were much more likely to refer the male students for an ADHD assessment than the female students (ADDitude, 2023). Kate (45, ADHD) laments that “I'm convinced even though I was a girl exhibiting very clear signs of ADHD, they didn't catch it because they thought only boys could behave like that. So I just got written off as too loud, too dramatic, too much!” Gender bias in existing screening tools and diagnostic criteria focus more on restlessness, fidgeting, and other signs of hyperactivity (traits typically associated with ADHD in boys and men) than they do on signs of inattention and emotional lability. Diagnostic criteria also fail to reflect the lived experiences of women with ADHD because they have been largely excluded from research studies. “Researchers have conceptualized

ADHD based on the male presentation, leading to many clinicians being unaware of the different symptom presentations that girls may express” (Schechter, 2022). Anna (49, ADHD) “was told there was a chance [she] wouldn’t ‘qualify’ to be diagnosed with ADHD because [she] didn’t present with difficulty in school before the age of 12. It goes to show how the DSM-5 needs to be updated to show how girls with ADHD present differently than boys.” Social norms, Stereotyping and Masking: Masking, otherwise known as social camouflaging, is when autistic people and people with ADHD hide their differences and conform to social expectations. As Kate, 45, puts it, “girls that have ASD and ADHD or both are wicked good at masking and are socialized to people please and tap dance harder and grind harder than everyone, so we are really good at hiding it!” This can involve consciously or unconsciously mimicking socially acceptable behaviors, like overcompensating for ADHD traits such as forgetfulness by obsessively checking belongings. Masking is further amplified by societal expectations and gender stereotypes that dictate women should be composed, organized, and in control. Due to this, ADHD traits can manifest very differently in girls and women as behaviours are often hidden and less conspicuous due to masking. For autistic girls, this can involve forcing facial expressions by copying others, suppressing or hiding stims like hand-flapping or echolalia, switching to subtler stims such as fiddling with a pen, and masking sensory sensitivities. While teachers may describe them as well-behaved, and they may cope well socially, prolonged masking can lead to after-school emotional collapse where girls may lash out at family. This is because the debilitating exhaustion of suppression and pent up energy from the day eventually implodes in environments that feel safe. Creating a calm, predictable home environment, allowing downtime after school, and validating feelings without judgment helps girls recover from the strain of masking. Julia (16, autistic) expresses that “I do find myself masking, but since my diagnosis I have gotten better at being myself and trying not to care if I seem too different. It can be hard to know when I’m masking, but I usually feel weird during and exhausted after.” The ADHD Presentation in girls: A girl with inattentive ADHD may be known as a “day-dreamer,” often in her own world, appearing disengaged. She might lose things often, have a low awareness of time, and find it hard to pay close attention to the details in a particular task. It might appear that she is doing fine because she usually meets or exceeds expectations at school. It will likely be draining for her to maintain this, but this is typically hidden. A girl with combined or hyperactive ADHD can be impulsive, chatty, driven, busy, a leader, and easily distracted. Unlike the typical stereotype of a young boy who is physically

hyperactive and “disruptive” (bouncing off the walls, blurting out answers), girls may have more subtle presentations, like hair twirling or constant doodling, which make it harder to attribute to an ADHD presentation. The diagnostic gap often widens during puberty, a period of immense developmental and hormonal change. As estrogen levels increase, some girls with ADHD experience a worsening of symptoms, particularly in areas like emotional regulation, attention, and mood stability. These changes, paired with rising academic and social pressures, often reveal difficulties that were either hidden or well-masked previously. Unfortunately, at this developmental phase, many of these girls are misdiagnosed with depression, anxiety, or other mood disorders instead of ADHD. ADHD is also generally marked by motivation difficulties due to differences in dopamine regulation and weaker activation in the pre-frontal cortex. Jenny, 52, recalls that “I would fall asleep in class. I would procrastinate starting an assignment and then only start when fear motivated me. I would rarely edit my papers because I wouldn’t have time. I would doodle a lot while listening but it would always look like I wasn’t paying attention.” “My messiness means I’m flexible and creative. I'm easily distracted but I notice details others miss. My restlessness means I make sand castles when I’m at the beach and I make fairy houses when camping. Even my emotional intensity means I have strong empathy and compassion. It’s easy to focus on the negatives but you need to keep reminding yourself of the positives (Jenny, 52, ADHD). The Autistic expression in girls: Autistic traits in girls are frequently missed, overlooked, and ignored, their behaviour put down to “just being a girl”. An autistic girl having a meltdown is called emotional and hysterical, because that’s how girls are stereotyped. An example of this may be an autistic girl who has an aversion to dirt. She might feel distressed at the texture and idea of it, yet may be praised because historically girls were expected to be clean and tidy. Autistic girls often have passionate interests which are viewed as more socially acceptable than the “special interests” of their male counterparts. For example, animals and reading are common passionate interests amongst girls. This is where societal expectations of women and girls can create barriers to recognising, understanding and supporting autistic girls. Autistic girls often engage in different repetitive behaviours than what is stereotypically autistic. This might not always look like lining up objects or repeating words out loud (known as echolalia). It may instead look like re-reading the same book or re-watching the same film over and over again because it provides a sense of comfort and predictability. It may involve re-doing homework until it’s “perfect” (it is common for autistic girls to be perfectionists), or repeating a certain behaviour that is comforting to them. There are also differences in academic environments. Julia expresses that “I have always been the last student to finish tests and assignments because I have a slow processing

speed. That means I think more deeply, which leads to better memory retention. I am also both more childish and more mature than my peers at the same time.” Unique Challenges Faced by Girls with Autism and/or ADHD: Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria (RSD) refers to the overwhelming emotional pain that comes from perceived rejection, criticism, or failure. Although not recognised as a formal diagnosis, RSD is widely reported among girls and women with ADHD and/or autism and is often described as one of the most destabilising aspects of their condition. Support strategies for parents/teachers: ● Saying feelings are “too much” can deepen shame. Acknowledging them shows you take their experience seriously. ● Modeling compassion for yourself shows that mistakes are part of being human, not signs of failure. ● Sensory breaks, breathing, or movement help manage overwhelm so they can think more clearly. ● Communicate and express yourself clearly and explicitly. ● Clear language reduces the chance of overthinking or misinterpreting intentions, which can easily trigger rejection fears. ● Be consistent with how you act around them. ● Predictability builds trust. Inconsistency (saying one thing, doing another) can feel like rejection or betrayal. Perfectionism arises when individuals place excessive pressure on themselves to meet unrealistically high standards. While it may sometimes be positively regarded as conviction or “striving for excellence,” the reality is often more complex. There is a fine line between healthy motivation and harmful perfectionism, and for many autistic and ADHD girls, women, and gender-diverse people, perfectionism is less about achievement and more about coping. Often, perfectionism is driven by fear of judgement, fear of being “not good enough,” or fear of exclusion. It can also be a form of masking, covering executive function difficulties and acting as a mechanism against criticism. This pattern is especially pronounced for those who also experience Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria, where imminent disapproval or rejection makes the pressure to appear flawless feel even more overwhelming. Support strategies for parents and teachers: ● Encourage a healthy sense of “good effort” and emphasize that things don’t have to be perfect to be done well. ● Talk about fluctuating capacity and remind students that “the best we could do” changes day to day, and that doing our best in the moment is enough. ● Reiterate that no one is perfect; mistakes are expected and are how we learn and grow, both at school and at home.

● Support positive self-talk and self-esteem as part of everyday learning. ● Break tasks into smaller, more achievable steps to make them manageable. ● Use time limits and the idea of “good enough” to help set boundaries, so tasks don’t stretch endlessly and students recognise when to stop. ● Praise effort rather than grades, but avoid comments like “Always do your best,” or “Was that really your best?” as they can fuel perfectionism and self-doubt. If you’re a parent, teacher, friend, or an autistic/ADHD female yourself, you may wish to share or read the following advice gathered from lived experience. “Take the time to invest in yourself and find pride in knowing how your brain works and share that whenever you can if it’s safe to do so. That requires bravery, and remembering that because you perceive the world differently and have likely taken in shame as a girl and as a neurodivergent girl, it takes even more bravery! But to remember you are brave and you have one life and you know you best! And also that all the cool kids have ADHD and ASD or both and so there's that, we are the cool table, 100%!!” (Kate, 45, ADHD) “Lean into what fires you up, because you’ll most probably make it. Don’t just do what everyone else is doing or expects you to do. That’s not where our strengths lie. Don’t let society/psychologists make you think there’s something wrong with how beautifully your brain moves through space and time.” (Anna, 49, ADHD) “If you know someone is saying something about you that's wrong, ignore them. Don’t worry if you’re not as good at something as a neurotypical. Focus on what you're good at and hone your abilities. Show the world that you can slay too.” (Laeticia, 15, autistic) “You are not broken or wrong in any way that has to do with your brain type. I would advise you to learn more about your unique strengths, to research about why so many neurodiverse females are late-diagnosed, and to not blame yourself for your challenges. Also, if you are in autistic burnout, you should not try to “just push through,” because that would prolong your discomfort. Instead, something that I find helpful is calming activities like doing a sticker book while being surrounded by fluffy things. The world can wait.” (Julia, 16, autistic) Resources: Books: 1. Geek Girl by Holly Smale 2. Drama Queen by Sara Gibbs 3. A Kind of Spark by Elle McNicoll 4. Safeguarding Autistic Girls 5. Strategies for Professionals by Carly Jones 6. The Secret Life of Rose: Inside an Autistic Head by Rose Smitten

7. Supporting Spectacular Girls by Helen Clarke 8. A Radical Guide for Women with ADHD by Michelle Frank and Sari Solden 9. Understanding Girls with ADHD by Kathleen G. Nadeau, Ellen Littman & Patricia O. Quinn 10. Understanding ADHD in Girls and Women by Sue Larkey 11. ADHD and Girls: An Introductory Guide by Suzanne Byrd Multimedia: 1. Jac den Houting – TEDxMacquarieUniversity 2. Why everything you know about autism is wrong 3. BBC Newsround – My Autism and Me 4. Podcast: Radical Self Acceptance for Women with ADHD with Sari Solden 5. Podcast: Understanding ADHD in Girls and the Importance of Encouraging Strengths with Dr Joanne Steer 6. ADHD Mums Podcast 7. Women & ADHD podcast with Katy Weber 8. ADHD Her Way podcast (host: Johanna Badenhorst) Websites: 1. ADDitude Magazine 2. Autistic Girls Network 3. Autism Empowerment Images: 1. https://life.london/2024/03/behind-the-mask-empowering-neurodivergent-women-in-t he-workplace/

Neurodiversity and Education: How to Support Neurodiverse Children in a Classroom By: Elizabeth Chai Editor: Joseph Leopold On average, around 15% to 20% of students in the world are neurodivergent, and most of them aren’t getting the educational support they need to succeed. Many teachers lack the proper resources and training to support neurodiverse children, and typical school environments can often be overwhelming for them. They are expected to learn in a standardized system that overlooks their strengths and the different ways they learn. Despite the accommodations offered to neurodiverse children, many schools face challenges in identifying and implementing the most effective strategies to optimize learning and comfort. In this article, two prominent models in special education will be explored: Self-contained classrooms and Integrated classrooms. Each approach offers its own experiences, challenges, and benefits. 1. Self-contained classrooms A self-contained classroom is a separate and specialized educational environment for neurodiverse students to learn together. This model was initially arranged in schools beginning in the 1960s, and ever since, they have been innovated to help maximize the learning and support of disabled students. These classrooms tend to have fewer students and are led by trained specialists and therapists who have experience working with children with diverse learning needs. Instead of the students moving around for each subject, the educator is responsible to instruct all of the material. Self-contained classrooms also provide more individualized support and modified curriculums based on a student’s individualized education plan (IEP). Personalized learning and increased support benefits students with more specific needs. Personalized curriculums

implement Universal Design Learning (UDL) principles to create accessible and engaging learning experiences. There are also therapeutic and behavioral interventions integrated in a classroom day for those who need it. Students have access to specialized resources and assistive technologies, such as AAC devices, text-to-speech softwares, or sensory tools to help with focus. Self-contained classrooms offer structured routines and an organized environment that can minimize distractions and promote a sense of predictability. This can reduce overstimulation and the anxiety of a student. Promoting inclusivity, neurodiverse children can foster a sense of belonging and create strong and meaningful connections with their peers, improving their social-emotional development. However, interactions between neurodivergent peers can also be limited, since they can sometimes be too different from each other. As this approach contains its own advantages, there are also certain challenges that come with it. If not carefully executed, neurodiverse students may face social isolation, due to not being able to communicate and learn alongside neurotypical peers. Optimizing interactions with them can be very helpful, which can take place during lunches or activities. Students can also develop stigmatic thoughts and feel labeled for being placed in a self-contained classroom, which is why promoting understanding and acceptance is important in school institutions. Self-contained classrooms may also face budgeting constraints, since they require more staff and specialized resources. Transitioning to mainstream classes in the future can also be difficult due to the lack of assistive technologies and curriculum flexibility, which is why educators should prepare them gradually. 2. Integrated classrooms

An integrated classroom allows neurodivergent students to learn alongside neurotypical peers in mainstream classrooms, where they are provided with accommodations and curriculum modifications to support different learning needs. Some common accommodations include extra time for assignments or tests, visual schedules, assistive technology, IEPs, and 504 plans. This approach aligns with the beliefs of the Individuals with Disabilities Act, advocating for unrestrictive learning environments for individuals with disabilities. First created in the 1960s as well, integrated classrooms are rising in popularity as teachers are finding ways to create classrooms that work for every child. There is always a general educational teacher and sometimes a special educating teacher, creating an integrated co-teaching approach (ICT). In ICTs, the two instructors collaborate to plan lessons that support diverse learning needs. All students are offered the same learning material and inclusivity is encouraged. Students have the opportunity to develop social and communication skills through interacting with peers of diverse abilities and backgrounds. Neurodiverse children benefit from these interactions, improving their social skills and behavior. Meanwhile, neurotypical students foster an understanding towards the values of diversity, respect, empathy, and collaboration. Being in mainstream classes allows full access to the curriculum, which comes with higher expectations and promotes academic growth of neurodiverse students. This also ensures easier long-term adjustments for them. Although, unlike in a self-contained classroom, neurodivergent students may be under-supported since some teachers don’t have the proper resources or training to provide necessary accommodations. They may feel overstimulated in the environment because of the noisiness, the larger class size, and the pace of instructions. Without proper peer education, they may be judged and misunderstood as well. Studies have also shown that despite putting neurodiverse children in integrated classrooms, their participation in group activities may still be limited to an extent. It is

important for teachers to encourage their engagement in learning and ensure they are being provided with the proper support. To conclude, there are two main approaches to support neurodiverse children in classrooms, each with their benefits and challenges. It is important to recognize how there isn’t a “correct” approach to optimize learning for children with diverse needs, and their placement should be individualized. The model that would benefit a neurodiverse individual the most depends on their specific strengths and needs. Self-contained classrooms work best when students need consistent support and a structure that excludes noisiness and overstimulation. Meanwhile, integrated classrooms are more ideal when schools have strong support systems with flexible teaching methods, and where neurodiverse students can benefit from social interactions and participate in the general curriculum. In general, schools make attempts to create integrated classrooms for neurodiverse children. A hybrid model may be optimal to some neurodiverse students, helping them build skills and gradually transitioning into mainstream classrooms. It is also essential to implement UDL principles and strength-based approaches into both classrooms. Ideally, these approaches can be further improved to fit the needs for each individual child. Resources: 1. https://www.education.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt326/files/inline-documents/sonh/fact-sh eet-rr-vs-sc-educational-environment_0.pdf 2. https://www.clrn.org/what-is-a-self-contained-classroom/?utm_source=chatgpt.com#Hist orical_Context_and_Evolution 3. https://www.friendshipcircle.org/blog/2016/11/21/inclusive-classrooms-vs-self-contained -classrooms 4. https://www.clrn.org/what-is-a-self-contained-classroom/?utm_source=chatgpt.com#Hist orical_Context_and_Evolution 5. https://www.ebsco.com/research-starters/education/self-contained-classrooms?utm_sourc e=chatgpt.com 6. https://www.ebsco.com/research-starters/education/integrated-co-teaching-ict?utm_sourc e=chatgpt.com 7. https://www.inclusiveeducation.ca/what-is-inclusive-education?utm_source=chatgpt.com 8. https://www.wonderbaby.org/articles/inclusive-classroom?utm_source=chatgpt.com Images: 1. https://thinksmartbox.com/news/five-ways-to-use-aac-in-the-classroom/ 2. https://www.ahead.ie/udl-framework 3. https://www.ascd.org/el/articles/neurodiversity-the-future-of-special-education

Neurodiversity & Short-form Content By: Jolie Wang Editor: Jacqueline Chen Ever want to know why you just can’t seem to escape the addictive hold short-form content has on you, especially if you have ADHD or Autism? Well, social media platforms are basically tailored to maintain your attention. How they do this is through a variety of ways that you may not notice as you scroll. Many of those methods are all centered around a key thing: dopamine. Dopamine: a chemical messenger (neurotransmitter) made in the brain and used for your body’s functions - including attention, memory, motivation, and more! It’s especially important with your brain’s reward system, helping you feel good and satisfied. (Cleveland Clinic) So what exactly are their tactics in making their content oh-so-irresistible? Content Personalization: Apps like TikTok and Instagram have algorithms that tailor to you. They work off of information such as the information of the short-form content (hashtags, sounds, and captions) and your account/device settings. As researchers

Mujica et al. put it, “ Social media systems are taking advantage of the system by increasing dopamine release via digital footprints and machine learning algorithms that flash personalized content. This reinforcement motivates extended use, while users find it harder to unplug due to the expectation of rewards.” More personalized media is more likely to continue user retention, because you know that what you’ll see will be what you like. User Interaction: User interactions are one of the ways these platforms work to get you engaged. Researchers, De et al., state that due to the personalized content you get because of these sites’ algorithms, comments, photo tagging, and likes, users anticipate and seek out rewards. These interactions are satisfying, which results in more dopamine. Then, as you interact with more things, the more information these algorithms have to work with - developing and continuing a cycle. Endless Consumption: Short-form content generally is a couple of seconds to a few minutes long. This, however, is not without reason. Consumption is quick - quick to watch, quick to share, and quick to scroll. Our Mental Health points out that this format for media can “provide rapid-fire stimulation, ideal for maintaining elevated dopamine levels,” which can result in “a cycle of compulsive checking and scrolling.” There are many more factors that social media platforms take into consideration. Such factors include how to hook your attention in and play with the brain’s relationship with dopamine. But how does this affect neurodiverse individuals? ADHD: As per Michael Asher and Lauren Aschler (experts in addiction and ADHD, respectively), individuals with ADHD have different dopamine system functions - leading to lower than average dopamine amounts. This is why those with ADHD struggle with motivation, focus, and impulse control, since dopamine is correlated to these things. Autism: Although the relationship between Autism and dopamine isn’t as clear as ADHD and dopamine, the former relationship is believed to exist. According to expert Muhammad Tuhin, abnormal dopamine signals are believed to correlate to the behavioral rigidity that those with Autism tend to be associated with. A study by Carbonell-Roig et al. suggests that the eukaryotic initiation factor 4E (eIF4E), a gene associated with autism risk, may impair the brain’s dopamine release. Why is this important? Well, for those who have these conditions, dopamine levels tend to inherently be an issue they face. With the increased use of social media in the present day, this means

that the impact of short-form content is more extreme for those individuals. Understanding how being neurodivergent goes a long way. But with how constant social media has become in many of our lives, understanding its impact as neurodivergent people helps us know ourselves even further. Resources: 1. https://www.ourmental.health/screen-time-sanity/tiktoks-dopamine-trap-the-a ddictive-power-of-short-form-videos 2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11804976/#REF27 3. https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/articles/22581-dopamine 4. https://www.sciencenewstoday.org/dopamine-dysfunction-linked-to-autism-inf lexibility 5. https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/changing-the-narrative-on-adhd/20 2406/dopamine-for-adhd-creating-a-dopa-menu?msockid=1c11bf6ed4a766a13cba ac54d5cd67c1 Images: 1. https://blog.adrianalacyconsulting.com/short-form-video-trends-marketing/

NeurodiversityandEntrepreneurship By: Claire Wang Editor: Pravin Balasingam The traditional workplace is often a stressful, frustrating environment for neurodivergent individuals. Recent employment studies have found that full-time employment levels for adults with ADHD are around 43% lower than neurotypical adults, and unemployment rates among adults with ASD may be as high as 80%. These statistics underscore that traditional work environments suppress neurodivergent qualities and compel individuals to meet neurotypical standards. However, entrepreneurship offers neurodivergent individuals the ability to create an environment that supports their needs and unlocks their full potential. A 2016 French study of small business owners found that when viewing ADHD symptoms through an entrepreneurial lens, “inattentiveness becomes a desire to imagine and discover unexplored terrains, hyperactivity becomes an aptitude for multitasking and innovation, and impulsivity becomes a trigger of risk-taking.” Similarly, individuals with ASD have good attention to detail, out-of-the-box thinking, determination, and persistence — important traits for entrepreneurship. When working in an appropriate environment, such as their own business, neurodivergent individuals can be regarded as assets rather than problems. They can implement business strategies that align with their cognitive styles and harness their skills to drive productivity and success while minimizing barriers. In 2021, autistic business owner G Sabini-Roberts gave a TED Talk arguing that we need to start promoting entrepreneurship as a viable career choice for neurodivergent individuals. They asserted that entrepreneurship can be a vehicle for neurodivergent individuals to “create businesses, to generate income and to build lives that allow their unique brilliance to shine without having to spend years in forms of employment that squash them or, even worse, teach them that they are incapable of succeeding.” By running their own business, neurodivergent

individuals can choose when, where, and how they can work — a huge step forward from the neurotypical workplaces that typically undervalue their talents. Many neurodivergent individuals have founded highly successful businesses. Barbara Corcoran, founder of the real estate business The Corcoran Group and investor on Shark Tank, struggled in school her whole life due to dyslexia but leveraged her experiences to overcome failures when starting her business. Corcoran claims that dyslexia made her “more creative, more social, and more competitive” and taught her to work on her own terms. David Neeleman, founder of five commercial airlines, including JetBlue, once said that if there were a pill he could take to make his ADHD go away, he would not take it. He credits his success to ADHD, noting, “I can distill complicated facts and come up with simple solutions… My ADD brain naturally searches for better ways of doing things.” It’s time for neurodivergent individuals to recognize entrepreneurship as a possible pathway to empowerment and success and for neurotypical individuals to support neurodiversity in the workplace by acknowledging and accommodating the unique strengths and challenges faced by neurodivergent employees. As G Sabini-Roberts put it, “You do not have to fit into the boxes that the world has been trying to put you into, because those boxes were not made for you. You can make your own box.” Sources: https://uptimize.com/neurodivergent-icons/ https://www.forbes.com/sites/dalearcher/2014/05/14/adhd-the-entrepreneurs-superpower/?sh=2ac8eb2159e9 https://fortune.com/2023/09/07/shark-tank-barbara-corcoran-dyslexia-millionaire-real-estate-success-entrepreneu r-richard-branson-kevin-oleary-daymond-john/ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPaiyPje1DA https://www.timeetc.com/resources/how-to-achieve-more/why-do-neurodiversity-and-entrepreneurship-make-su ch-good-business-partners Images: https://www.information-age.com/why-its-important-to-understand-embrace-neurodiversity-at-work-123500934/ https://www.barbaracorcoran.com/about/ https://www.bjtonline.com/business-jet-news/david-neeleman-0

Celebrating Neurodiversity in Art and Expression Art has always been deemed an outlet to express oneself, whether celebrating pure bliss and jubilance or acknowledging our internal sorrows and grief. However, art – which can include visual arts, tactile art, musical art, physical art, etc. — can also be vital in communication for neurodivergent individuals. Compared to traditional strategies and interventions that heavily involve verbalization, talking alone may not be the best approach for neurodivergent individuals. Verbalization may be frustrating and impossible for some, where finding the right words to express their thoughts and emotions is a struggle. However, art comes as a non-verbal alternative that many take, as it provides a creative, innovative, and expressive experience. While there are various art forms, individuals may respond better to one art form compared to the other. Exploring different materials and different forms of art allows neurodiverse individuals to communicate via rhythm, sounds, images, movements, gestures, or vocalizations. Through this, art can become a pathway for them to convey their emotions, thoughts, and sensations. One major benefit of utilizing an art-based approach is sensory processing. Because certain art forms such as painting or sculpting involve exposure to different, or occasionally unpleasant stimuli, it can allow individuals to overcome sensory issues or increase tolerance for these stimuli. Additionally, partaking in a more art-based approach can improve fine motor skills, focus, and other vestibular functions. Art is an outlet for self-expression and a form of communication for neurodiverse individuals. Utilizing an artistic approach has many benefits, many of which are still under study. For those who struggle with the traditional approaches of verbal therapy, art may provide a better alternative, ensuring multiple opportunities to communicate.

Sources: - Expressive Arts Are Neurodiversity-Affirming | Psychology Today - Western Carolina University - The Way I’m Wired: Artist Reflections on Neurodiversity (wcu.edu) - Neurodiversity and Creativity (besharamagazine.org) - The Guggenheim Museums and Foundation - (20) Art in Neurodivergence: A Spectrum of Possibilities | LinkedIn

Neurodiversity Celebration Week By Vedhika Mohankumar The term neurodiverse was first introduced when an Australian sociologist, Judy Singer, coined the word to acknowledge the idea that everyone's brain develops uniquely. Since then, the neurodiversity advocacy movement has seen dramatic progress. This year, Neurodiversity Celebration Week (NCW) took place from March 18th to March 24. It is a week where advocacy is at its highest and emphasizes the importance of embracing neurodiversity in our community. In 2018, NCW was founded by Siena Castellon, who strived to change how people perceived learning differences. The week celebrates the achievements and contributions of neurodiverse individuals in various fields. Many see it as a week to challenge neurodiverse stereotypes and misconceptions. This week helps raise awareness, promote acceptance, and celebrate the strengths of neurodiverse individuals. Through workshops, seminars, and educational programs, this week aims to advocate and celebrate neurodiversity. By providing insights into the experiences of neurodiverse individuals, we are able to dispel myths about the neurodiverse community and foster understanding. The week also provides advocacy in education by promoting supportive learning environments and encouraging the implementation of inclusive practices that accommodate diverse learning styles and needs.

Neurodiversity Celebration Week is a significant step in advocacy as it promotes awareness and celebration. Events are hosted throughout the week with talks from experts, Q&As, and discussions. Talks range from introductions to neurodiversity to in-depth conversations about neurodiversity in the workplace, the experiences of girls, and mental health. Researching and participating in the numerous events, along with the word about NCW can help support and spread awareness for neurodiversity. Sources ● https://www.neurodiversityweek.com/ ● https://www.washington.edu/doit/what-do-%E2%80%9Cneurodiverse%E2%80%9D-and -%E2%80%9Cneurodivergent%E2%80%9D-mean

Exploring Neurodiversity in Video Games: A Path Towards Inclusivity and Empowerment Author: Nyshita Chalasani Editor: Alice Barton In recent years, the gaming industry has undergone a notable transformation, embracing a more inclusive approach that acknowledges the diverse spectrum of players engaging with video games. This shift extends beyond technological advancements; it reflects a profound recognition of the unique needs and contributions of all gamers, including those who are neurodiverse. Neurodiversity, encompassing a range of neurological differences such as autism, ADHD, and dyslexia, is gaining increasing recognition and appreciation within gaming communities. This article delves into the intersection of neurodiversity and video games, exploring how inclusive trends are reshaping the gaming landscape. It examines specific accommodations tailored to neurodiverse players and examines the positive impacts of gaming on individuals with diverse neurological profiles. Neurodiverse Gamers The digital world of gaming has become a sanctuary for many neurodiverse individuals, offering an environment where they can express themselves freely, engage in social interactions on their terms, and enjoy a level of control often not available in the real world. The prevalence of neurodiverse gamers underscores the need for the gaming industry to recognize and cater to their unique needs. By embracing neurodiversity, developers can create games that are not only more accessible but also more engaging for a broader audience that is often forgotten about. Inclusive Game Design The heart of inclusivity in video games lies in thoughtful game design. Developers are increasingly incorporating features that make games more accessible to neurodiverse players. Customizable settings that allow players to adjust sensory inputs, such as brightness and sound levels, are becoming standard. Furthermore, the introduction of adaptive difficulty levels enables players with varying cognitive abilities to enjoy gaming at their own pace, making the virtual worlds more welcoming and less frustrating. Examples of such inclusive design can be seen in mainstream titles that offer extensive accessibility options, including remappable controls, colorblind modes, and subtitles for those

with hearing impairments. These features not only aid neurodiverse gamers but also improve the overall gaming experience for all players. Specific Accommodations Beyond game design, gaming platforms themselves are evolving to become more inclusive. Features that facilitate easier communication can significantly benefit those with social anxiety or communication difficulties, offering alternative text-based chatting options or customizable avatars that help express emotions and reactions non-verbally. Accessibility settings tailored to individuals with motor skill challenges, such as single-handed control schemes or eye-tracking technology, are becoming more prevalent, ensuring that gaming is an activity everyone can enjoy. Positive Impact of Gaming The impact of gaming on neurodiverse individuals extends far beyond entertainment. For many, online multiplayer platforms have become a vital space for socializing and building connections through similar interests, often leading to long-lasting friendships. These virtual interactions can significantly enhance social skills, providing a comfortable environment for neurodiverse individuals to communicate and collaborate with others. Moreover, gaming can serve as a valuable tool for development. Engaging with video games can improve cognitive skills, such as problem-solving, spatial awareness, and strategic planning. Additionally, video games can aid in the development of fine motor skills and coordination, providing a fun and effective way for neurodiverse individuals to practice and enhance these abilities. Challenges and Opportunities Despite the strides made towards inclusivity, challenges remain in fully accommodating the multitude needs of neurodiverse gamers. Accessibility features are not yet universal, and the cost of adaptive technologies can be prohibitive for many. Moreover, there is a need for greater representation of neurodiversity within the games narratives and characters, which can foster a deeper sense of belonging and acceptance among neurodiverse players.

The path forward offers exciting opportunities for collaboration between developers, neurodiverse communities, and accessibility advocates. Through continued dialogue and partnership, the gaming industry can further innovate and refine the ways in which games are designed, developed, and deployed; ensuring that gaming remains a welcoming and empowering space for all players. Conclusion The journey towards embracing neurodiversity in the gaming world is ongoing, driven by a commitment to inclusivity, understanding, and respect for all players. By highlighting the specific needs and contributions of neurodiverse gamers, developing more inclusive games, and celebrating the positive impacts of gaming, the industry can create a vibrant, diverse community where everyone has the opportunity to play, grow, and connect. As we move forward, the vision of a fully inclusive gaming ecosystem becomes not just a possibility but an achievable reality, enriching the gaming experience for all.

CBT and Neurodivergence (Part 1) Basics of CBT By: Jerry Yang and Ella Guan Editor: Alice Barton Introduction Human beings, neurodivergents included, are sentient beings who can not only sense what is around them but can make deep meaning and emotions out of information acquired from their senses. People make actions not only based on the results of senses from environmental stimuli but also based on their thoughts and feelings. Our feelings are not the result of our current situation but our thoughts that come from perceiving and interpreting our current situation. How The Cognition Cycle Works: Here is a simple yet more accurate model that interprets how our brains work: 1. We have a current situation we are in 2. We have thoughts based on our current situation 3. We feel emotions based on our thoughts 4. We develop behaviors and act based on our feelings 5. The situation changes based on our behaviors and actions Our capability of thought is however often mired in cognitive distortions- irrational and maladaptive nasty thinking patterns such as mental filters, biases, trends,

perceptions, and more. This can make us feel awful emotions which would lead us to develop maladaptive behaviors and actions that make our situations and environments worse. Cognitive distortions occur especially when people are experiencing depression, extreme stress, and other mental health afflictions. Because neurodivergent individuals are at higher risk for developing these mental health afflictions, along with other factors related to neurodivergence such as stigma and discrimination, they are at especially high risk of possessing these cognitive distortions. https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5cb61b1e29f2cc34d16e2bd6/1621978812267-8YUB56N4TM2TEUT2HMUF/downward-spiral-depression.png Classical behavioral science and therapy primarily focus on our behaviors, their development, and their consequences. However, this doesn’t really take into account our thoughts and feelings and how they affect behaviors and decisions, so it’s suboptimal for fixing behaviors arising from irrational thinking patterns. It would require cognitive psychology which in part deals with cognitions – the thoughts that we have based on perceiving our surroundings. What is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy? Cognitive Behavioral Therapy teaches us to effectively monitor our feelings, thoughts, and behaviors, how they influence each other, and how to find and replace negative ones with positive ones. It finds and replaces them with more realistic, evidence-supported, and positive thoughts. Because thoughts influence feelings and behaviors, it will make us feel invigorated to take steps towards getting back in control. Although you can’t suddenly change your current situation, you can change your attitude about the situation. This can be profoundly helpful, as thoughts drive feelings which drive actions. More realistic, positive, and productive thoughts can make you feel more happy, motivated, and in control, leading to actions that improve your situation. You can use the following graphic worksheet below as a guide to practice CBT.

(both positive positive and thinking patterns and negative) helpful thoughts and thoughts. that will happen and write them if you take these down here. actions. We can’t We can and Influenced by Influenced by Consequences change this should focus on our thoughts our feelings of actions initially changing these first Now it’s time to identify some cognitive distortions and learn the right ways to counter them. Examples Of Cognitive Distortions Cognitive distortions negatively warp your perception of reality, and in fact, it’s difficult to identify them as your brain habitually believes its current perception is rational and factual. It can be hard for the brain to unlearn after long periods of training. Thankfully, CBT teaches us how to identify cognitive distortions. We will be going over some examples.

https://themighty.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/EgNRNxBXgAAQlmc-562x750.jpg 1. Extreme Thinking All Or Nothing Thinking: If something doesn’t go perfectly it is a complete failure. Even a minor screw-up spells total failure with this thinking. Another variant is if they can’t do something perfectly, it would be pointless for them to try. Victims of this distortion easily claim defeat. This could make them quit tasks midway, preventing them from completing difficult yet rewarding endeavors. They would also avoid seeking out golden opportunities for self-improvement, accomplishments, and success. https://sova.pitt.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/All-or-nothing-thinking.jpg Overgeneralization: Taking a few bad examples of something and using them to overgeneralize that something is completely awful. A person thinking like this could

believe that something negative that happens occasionally would always happen to them. This can lead to people overestimating the negativity of their situation, killing their optimism, passion, and willpower to continue trying. https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5ce9d5f46530d90001fa1b54/1640038845884- WEKTO95MOCBWAE5UVMK3/Overgeneralization.jpg Black And White Thinking: Thinking a person or situation is completely something or something else, with no levels in between. In reality, there always will be in-betweens and nuances. This can result in unfounded and drastic view changes, with a single negative experience completely ruining one’s views on something. One could describe aspects of themselves, others, or their experiences with extreme wording such as “always” or “never”, or as completely negative. This can cause themselves and others to feel worse than they should, worsening interactions and relations with others and driving them down a spiral of negativity. https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5c8facb1fb22a57f65bacf1d/1579540660453-LUVTUXBHERAUMZU0G3O8/Black-White-Thinking-2.png 2. Poor Predictions Catastrophizing: Assuming the worst possible cases have happened or are most likely. This is irrational if there’s little to no supporting evidence or plenty of refuting evidence. Tricking your brain into believing a situation is exaggeratedly worse overwhelms you with negative emotions and may prevent you from taking helpful actions. The same goes for tricking your brain into thinking the worst is most likely to happen.

https://i.pinimg.com/474x/7e/e7/78/7ee7788ce3520c35a121eba1eb3ff38c.jpg Mind Reading: Assuming what and how other people know and think about you. For example, you assume that people have negative impressions of you and are annoyed by your actions. In reality, people are probably feeling overall neutral if not positive about you. Mind reading can cause an individual to feel unnecessarily vindictive, anxious, or upset based on assumptions that lack reason. Personalization: Assuming everything that is happening around you, even things out of your control, is to a disproportionate degree caused by you. By doing this you are unfoundedly placing blame on yourself for the wrongdoings of others or factors outside your control, giving yourself extra stress, anxiety, and self-loathing. You may also think that the reason why others are acting negatively around or towards you is because of you; in reality, their day was likely tainted by another factor.

https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1400/1*9MuxTeSZIWgzqGd-p0075w@2x.jpeg 3. Absolute Labeling Labeling: Putting an absolute label on yourself or someone based on occasions. These names/labels tend to be an inflated and inaccurate reflection of their qualities. A name is a powerful thing! If you label yourself as something negative like an “incompetent idiot” repeatedly, you’d believe you inherently and permanently possess these characteristics, creating a blanket of hopelessness blocking growth. The same happens to others when you label them. https://static.oprah.com/images/o2/201506/201506-omag-beck-1-949x534.jpg Flawed Filters Mental Filtering: Focusing only on one side of a situation and filtering out all other sides. For example, focusing on the negatives while ignoring the positives. This will result in you undermining the positive actions and progress you have made and constantly dwelling on your failures and flaws. You could belittle your positive efforts as futile, which would make you overwork, overstress, or give up. You could undermine your strengths, making yourself feel devoid of positive traits. You could act this way towards other people around you, such as ignoring the positive things others have done and pestering them on their flaws, burning ties between you and them.

https://www.manhattancbt.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/half-full-vs-half-empty-mental-filt er.jpg Unreal-Idealistic Comparison: Excessively and unfairly comparing yourself to others. If you are in a fairly turbulent situation and everyone around you seems to be handling the same or similar situation fine, you might get upset and blame yourself for struggling. Most likely, people around you are also struggling. You might also compare your shortcomings to others’ strengths while ignoring your strengths and others’ shortcomings. This is the perfect recipe for an inferiority complex. https://csusmchronicle.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Social-Media-Graphic-13.2-.png Emotional Reasoning Feelings = Reality: Thinking your feelings accurately reflect on your reality. If you experience a certain negative emotion, this cognitive distortion can trick you into thinking something is actually wrong. You might also feel hurt by others’ innocent or even positive actions and accuse others of being hurtful when they weren’t or weren’t intentionally. By letting your negative and irrational emotions impact your thoughts, your thoughts will further amplify those emotions, creating a nasty feedback loop.

Root Causes For Cognitive Distortions Like how all ways of thinking are developed, your brain might have evolved cognitive distortions for short-term benefits, such as protection against certain threats, coping mechanisms for harsh experiences, or fixing a past problem. However, in the long term, they instead contribute to mental health issues or even an unfulfilling and unsuccessful life. Here are a couple of potential reasons leading to the development of distortions. Always Expecting The Worst: Some cognitive distortions are evolved to protect oneself from disappointment, shock, and anguish from experiencing a sudden overwhelming wave of adversity. Some people, would rather always expect the worst and not be surprised when misfortune hits them than have reasonably optimistic expectations and be unprepared and overwhelmed with sudden adversity. This stems from natural fear and vulnerability towards unexpected adversity or past prolonged streaks of negative experiences. These cognitive distortions seem to work temporarily by saving us from experiencing unexpected letdowns, but in the long run, you’re starved of positive emotions, experiences, and endeavors of self-improvement. https://ih1.redbubble.net/image.701271822.9850/raf,750x1000,075,t,101010:01c5ca27c6.u2.jpg Avoiding Risk and Effort: A lot of rewarding and beneficial actions we pursue in life require a lot of efforts and could even be risky with failure yielding negative consequences. This could cause us to avoid them due to our fear of trying and failure, fear of futile efforts, fear of responsibility, and laziness. Past consecutive streaks of failures and wasted efforts can easily drive us to avoid seeking and pursuing potentially risky yet rewarding enterprises. Related cognitive distortions make golden excuses to not put hard work into actions which bring positive impact, exacerbating a downward spiral.

https://cdn-webimages.wimages.net/051fa8cf5fd001a34f30ac5aa614eb4c84bfdb-v5-wm.jpg?v=3 Comfort In Labeling: Labels could provide a good explanation, excuse, or acceptance for your incompetence in an area. It’s fine to accept yourself as someone who possesses those weaknesses, but it’s unacceptable to use labels to excuse yourself from putting in hard work to improve upon those weaknesses. Doing that would only make you feel permanently inferior, incapable, and like a failure. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/trust-me-im-failure-karen-heng Conclusion and Next Steps We have covered the basics of cognitive distortions, their effects, and why we develop them. By knowing the possible causes and origins of our cognitive distortions, we can then create replacement thoughts that address those target causes. In the next article CBT and Neurodivergence (Part 2) Applying CBT, we’ll cover some counters to cognitive distortions, how neurodivergent people can use CBT, as well as drawbacks and alternatives to CBT. Remember, regardless of your identity, you have the power to make yourself good at anything you dedicate effort, perseverance, and optimism to. Don’t let your disabilities, shortcomings, and other disadvantages in life hold you back from achieving greatness.

CBT and Neurodivergence (Part 2) Applying CBT By: Jerry Yang and Ella Guan Editor: Alice Barton Introduction In Part 1, we discussed cognitive distortions, and how they negatively impact our lives. We also delve into their origins and reasons for development. Armed with this understanding, we can turn the tide as long as we display consistent effort, perseverance, and optimism. In Part 2, we will go over various strategies to replace distorted thoughts. We will introduce ways to apply CBT to our own lives but also acknowledge some imperfections of the therapy for neurodiverse individuals. Countering Distortions Here are some very good ways you can conjure effective replacement thoughts to counter cognitive distortions. Cost Benefit Analysis: The squares in the worksheet provided earlier have asked to state both positive and negative thoughts/feelings/actions/consequences. This reflects upon the idea that we may’ve developed and stuck to these distortions in the hope of some comfort or resolution to our problems. Compare the positives and negatives created by your initial flawed thinking patterns to those of the new replacement thoughts. Hopefully, you’d have figured out new replacement thoughts which yield much better net outcomes than your initial cognitive distortions.

https://image.slideserve.com/212986/cost-benefit-analysis-l.jpg Reality-Check: Are your perception and thinking backed up by reality? Put effort into reality-checking yourself and search your surroundings for evidence that supports or refutes your thinking. Are people around you actually angry or disappointed around you, or are they neutral or praising you? Are you actually failing or making progress in the long run? Your emotions are likely not the most reliable source of evidence either and could falter to emotional reasoning. https://thumbs.dreamstime.com/b/reality-check-28967744.jpg Changing Roles And Perspectives: Try to view your situation in different ways such as from alternative perspectives. Think of your case and think from the perspective of others, such as your friends, peers, and bosses. If you told them about your thoughts, how would they think of and respond towards them? How would you respond if another person had the same cognitive distortions you have and they sought your help? If you would respond in a mild and positive manner, other reasonable people would likely do the same.

https://kajabi-storefronts-production.global.ssl.fastly.net/kajabi-storefronts-production/blogs/26395/images/NC43bBfFTvq ONozXB7Wg_Slide1.jpeg Exorcise Extremes And Generalization: Try to catch yourself saying or thinking in extremes and overgeneralizations. Is a statement saying something is completely negative in a certain way partially incorrect? It very likely is. Try to come up with counter examples to that statement. For example, if you think you’re utterly incompetent, try to see in grey and list situations where you have demonstrated both competency and ineptness. Avoid extreme wording such as “worst”, “only”, “completely”, and “never” in your vocabulary and thinking. Everything has pros and cons. https://student-tutor.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Words-to-Avoid.jpg Ways to Apply CBT

There are many ways that one can apply CBT therapy, making it a very adaptable method that many people can use effectively. For example, group therapy may not be the best option for neurodiverse individuals who get overwhelmed in an environment with a lot of people; you can do one-on-one CBT between a suitable therapist and a neurodivergent individual. A specialized CBT therapist can guide clients through identifying their unique negative thoughts and replace them in a way best suited for them. For some neurodivergent individuals who enjoy the company of other neurodivergents, group therapy is a good choice and can create an environment for people to work together on the CBT therapy process, especially on focusing on combating common negative ideas, and getting to know other neurodivergent perspectives. Additionally, there are also many self-help resources like books and workbooks that can be done from home. Finally, once you have learned to recognize negativity, you can apply CBT principles beyond therapy sessions to create more positive relationships. For neurodivergents such as people with autism and/or ADHD, anxiety is often a major hindering factor in their daily lives, as they are considerably more likely to possess overall higher anxiety levels than neurotypicals. They are also more likely to have trouble coping with emotional distress, problem-solving, and social skills, and are substantially more likely to develop anxiety and depression. CBT when adapted and implemented properly can be very effective at teaching them how to counter these problems. Although CBT might be somewhat difficult for people on the autism spectrum as it requires strong linguistic, emotional processing and identification, and abstract thinking abilities, it is still a method that would yield great boons once fully mastered and is greatly worth pursuing in most scenarios. Many autistic children, however, have shown fluency with distinguishing thoughts, feelings, and behaviors and altering their thoughts, yet having only trouble identifying emotions. Autistic people would want to find ways to make CBT more structured and repetitive as well as more visualizable and concrete. Autistic people can also focus on developing social skills, independent living skills, and emotional identification and regulation while reducing anxiety and frustrations caused by those departments when using CBT. In recent years, there has been an increasing number of ADHD-specialized CBT programs. ADHD people could have developed cognitive distortions due to a lifetime of failures, setbacks, and barriers caused by societal stigma and various ADHD

symptoms such as executive functioning problems. These programs have incorporated CBT as an effective addition to building executive functioning habits and skills such as organization and staying on task, as well as building self-esteem, emotional regulation, and pride. CHADD, Attention Deficit Disorder Association, and the ADDitude Directory are great places to hook up with specialists providing these programs. https://i0.wp.com/post.healthline.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/woman-therapist-talking-to-female-patient-1296x7 28-header.jpg?w=1155&h=1528 Drawbacks and Alternatives CBT is popular because it is research proven and evidently effective; however, there is less evidence of success with neurodiverse clients, with several potential drawbacks. For example, autistic people and some individuals with ADHD have difficulty with flexible thinking; however, the core of CBT is teaching patients to change their way of thinking and their interpretation of events and information. CBT exercises that involve cognitive restructuring are generally very difficult for many neurodiverse people who have trouble with flexible thinking. Additionally, many neurodiverse individuals face difficulties with forming clear and robust verbal communication and understanding. CBT requires a robust link of communication and understanding between the therapist and the client. CBT focuses on changing the way someone thinks. For many neurodiverse people, forcing change in the way they think, especially in ways against their brain’s

structural differences, is really challenging. Many neurodiverse individuals are also beginning to embrace various symptoms and differences as simply neurological differences rather than disorders or illnesses to be treated. Thankfully though this could allow CBT to play in the favor of the neurodiverse, as CBT’s nature of reducing negativity and increasing acceptance can trigger positive outlooks on neurological differences. One way to ensure a positive CBT experience is to find a therapist knowledgeable and understanding of the sensory sensitivities, communication styles, and other traits and needs of neurodiverse individuals. Additionally, there are alternative therapies that may synergize better with various neurodiverse conditions. Here is a list of therapies that are good alternatives to CBT: - Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT) is a modular therapy that develops mindfulness, distress tolerance, trauma coping, and emotional regulation, good for ND people with extreme past trauma and mood disorders - Applied Behavioral Analysis (ABA) finds functional relationships between environments, behaviors, and consequences for behavioral adjustments and has a specific and structured nature that may excel with autism - Rational Emotive Behavior Therapy (REBT) helps apply rational thinking to emotion management, especially with dealing with adversity - Neurodivergent-Affirming Therapy (NAT) can help ND people turn their differences into advantages while giving them pride in their differences and identity

https://assets-global.website-files.com/61b8e7cc67e74168f1c53f45/626078e7d31d8a45c84f58c4_62349b56cb795449b9f0773c_Copy%20of%20Grouport%20Socia l%20Media%20(1300%20%C3%97%201080%20px)-p-800.png https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/5a40d583f6576e1abec2c509/1649244359547-GIGPXNPZCK3LIWXAOPXU/Untitled+%28800+%C3%97+600+px% 29+%284%29.png?format=1000w https://fourweekmba.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/rational-emotive-therapy.png https://www.autismpartnershipsg.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/2.png Conclusion Cognitive Behavioral Therapy can be a very powerful tool for neurodiverse individuals struggling with mental health issues due to living in a world full of all sorts of barriers. For many, it helps with combating negative thought patterns. However, there are often many limitations with CBT for neurodiverse people due to its need for emotional management, flexible thinking, and other requirements, many of which are extra strenuous for neurodiverse individuals. That doesn’t mean that CBT can’t be adapted to work around these challenges, but other alternatives should also be tried. Eliminating the negativity that often arises for neurodiverse individuals is an important step to building a society of inclusivity, equality, and belonging. To all fellow neurodivergent and neurotypicals out, don’t let your identity-based disadvantages and life’s painful setbacks hold you back from achieving your greatest dreams. You all can shine no matter what you are made of.

Neurodiversity and the recent emergence of music therapy SourceforImage What is music therapy? Music therapy, also known as neurologic music therapy (NMT), is a form of psychological and physical therapy surrounding music, including songwriting, sas to music, music improvisation, etc. Engaging in musical intervention can help accomplish individual non-musical goals. People can use music therapy as a form of emotional expression and communication. Currently, professionals use music therapy in various medical conditions– aiding traumatic brain injuries, stroke, autism, Alzheimer’s, and Parkinson's disease are some of the many applications. Research on music therapy shows that it can activate various parts of the brain, specifically cognitive, motor, and speech centers. For cognitive treatments, music therapy stimulates the brain, introducing timing, grouping, and better organization, ultimately improving attention, memory, auditory perception, and executive function. In speech and language NMT treatments, it influences fluency, vocalization, oral motor control, and comprehension. A common method for speech and language is singing. For motor treatments, auditory rhythm improves balance, coordination, and dexterity. In most cases, musical instruments are the most widely used form of therapy to accomplish motor rehabilitation. How is music therapy utilized for neurodivergent individuals? Music therapy mainly activates the parts of the brain in charge of sensory and auditory functions. This form of therapy may benefit those with difficulties with sensory processing, communication, non-verbal expression, etc. Among those who struggle with motor movement, the entertainment and immersion of music encourage movement in accordance with the tempos and rhythms of the song.

Marching, walking, or even jumping to the beat helps the physical body feel more organized and confident. With neurodiverse individuals who struggle more with dexterity and coordination of the left hand and right hand, a music therapist may suggest using mallets, sticks, piano, or other two-handed instruments. By practicing these instruments repeatedly, continuous rehearsal would result in greater motor control and body dexterity in general. Singing would be a highly effective form of musical therapy and treatment for individuals who struggle with verbal communication or reciprocating conversation. Because singing requires both hemispheres of the brain, it can help nonverbal individuals and those struggling with stuttering, aphasia, or apraxia. The initial steps to this music therapy would start with a hum of one or two notes followed by free-flowing vocal sounds. Gradually, the music therapist would increase the tempo to match the tempo to the speed of a normal conversation. Another form of vocal music therapy is musical conversation, which is to help develop reciprocal communication. Singing back and forth in melodic hums teaches when to speak and when to wait, mimicking a conversation. Neurodivergent individuals have increasingly used music therapy due to its significant benefits. The various forms of musical engagement, ranging from singing to playing an instrument, can help individuals accomplish their goals. With increasing encouragement to try music therapy, it is always best to consult one’s primary doctor to see whether it would be the right path.

Neurodivergent actors Dan Aykroyd in 1984 Ghostbusters. Dan Akroy Dan Akroy is a 71-year-old actor and writer. He is known for his role as Ray Stantz in Ghostbusters. He has written and acted in many parts of the Ghostbusters franchise. He was in the 1980 movie The Blues Brothers and has been involved in other entertainment media. When he was 12 years old, after being expelled from two different schools, he was diagnosed with Tourette’s syndrome. He had physical tics but by 14 with the help of therapy, his symptoms eased. In the 1980s he was diagnosed with Asperger's. In an interview with CBS’s George Stephinopolus, he says “I was able to overcome it and channel it creatively.” He was captivated with ghosts and law enforcement from a young age, saying "One of my symptoms included my obsession with ghosts and law

enforcement—I carry around a police badge with me, for example. I became obsessed by Hans Holzer, the greatest ghost hunter ever. That’s when the idea of my film Ghostbusters was born." He got obsessed with a famous ghost hunter stating, “That was when the idea of my film The Ghostbusters was born.” He is very open about how his experiences being neurodivergent have changed his life and shaped him. Emma Watson at 2022’s BAFTAs red carpet. Emma Watson Emma Watson is a 33 year old actress. She is best known for her role in the Harry Potter movies and is also celebrated for playing Belle in the 2017 live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast. Other roles include movies such as Perks of Being a Wallflower, The Bling Ring, and Little Women, to name a few. Emma Watson has been diagnosed with ADHD and has been medicated since childhood. She has accredited her ADHD for her ability to hyperfocus on her

passions, including her schooling and acting career. She uses her large platform to raise awareness of neurodiversity and advocate for mental health. She is a strong-willed passionate woman. Mark Ruffalo at the She Hulk premiere. Mark Ruffalo Mark Ruffalo is a 55 year old actor. He is best known for playing the Hulk in the Marvel cinematic universe. He has had roles in The Adam Project, Now You See Me, 13 Going On 30, and Spotlight. He currently has 4 upcoming projects in various stages of production. He has been diagnosed with dyslexia and ADHD. He has three children: all of them diagnosed with dyslexia and two of them diagnosed with ADHD. He said as a child grade school was hard feel: strange, unique, and freakish. He says he would like his younger self to know there is help and there are ways to deal with it (Youtube, 5 Jun. 2017).

She previously played Regina George on Broadway's Mean Girls Musical and is currently planning to be in the Mean Girls Musical movie. Neurodiversity and Standardized Testing for Colleges Since the 1900s, most colleges in the United States have used standardized tests such as the SAT and ACT to help determine whether a student is qualified for admission. However, such evaluations can make the college application process more di�cult, and especially so for neurodiverse students. Furthermore, while the tests are supposed to help schools gain a better understanding of a student’s intellectual level, research has called into question the e�ectiveness of such evaluation. For example, Bates, the liberal arts college in Maine, has been test-optional since 1984 but required admitted students to submit scores upon matriculation for research purposes. In 2004, they released data from their experience, where they found only a 0.1% di�erence in graduation rates between submitters and nonsubmitters, and that the non-submitters who had scored much lower points on their standardized tests actually had higher graduation rates. Since the pandemic, many colleges have started to make standardized tests optional in the college application process. Mary Churchill of InsideHigherEdshares that more than 80% of colleges in the United States are test-optional as of 2023. But what does this really mean? As it sounds like, test-optional schools will not require students to submit test scores from the SAT or ACT when applying. However, this does not mean that they won’t lookat test results when submitted (that would be test blind). This makes it crucial when deciding if you should take a standardized test as part of your application or not. The SAT and ACT were designed for neurotypical people and therefore may present a number of challenges for neurodiverse students. The tests often include long passages of text, require lengthy instructions and o�er little time and a running timer. According to Sol Smith, all types of neurodiverse students can have trouble reading, noting that “the reasons could be visual or related to attention”. A neurotypical student might spend about a minute or less reading the instructions, while neurodiverse people often take much longer and may have to reread it several times. Neurodiverse students have ways to seek help, but oftentimes these methods or accommodations don’t fully solve the problem. At many schools, neurodiverse students can seek accommodations by reaching out to the College Counseling Center at their school, or the Learning Specialist (if they have one). However,

according to one anonymous learning specialist, “for example, just because you have ADHD or dyslexia or whatever, doesn't mean you necessarily need extra time, often you do, but not always, so there has gotta be a justification.” The College Board website a�rms this idea of justification clearly, stating seven important guidelines for requesting accommodations, including a test to prove your diagnosis. One example of an accommodation is extended time, which can definitely help, but let’s not forget that this can simultaneously make it more di�cult for neurodiverse students. For example, while students with ADHD may need more time to complete it, their focus may also fade over an extended time. It is also important to take into consideration the changes being made to some of these standardized tests and how they might impact you. By the spring of 2024, the SAT will only be delivered online instead of on paper. For some students, the online format may be preferred. The new online SAT (and PSAT) o�ers various features for all students with or without accommodations to access, such as the ability to zoom, a calculator, a math reference sheet, an annotator, and a “mark for review” button for questions students wish to return to. I talked to a college counselor and a learning specialist at my school to get their opinions on the matter. According to her, “Colleges look much more closely at grades and extracurriculars than test scores, and those tend to be areas that have more built-in support for neurodiverse students. A trend we're seeing is that for very highly ranked colleges, students are only submitting test scores if they fall within a small, very high range, so for students whose scores don't fall within that range, it's generally not in their best interest to dedicate the time and energy needed to boost a score by several hundred points - and that's true regardless of a student's circumstances, neurodiversity, or other factors. If testing would detract from a student's well-being in a meaningful way (taking time away from grades, other activities, or sleep, for instance), it's better to focus that energy on those other areas.” Ultimately, for any neurodiverse students faced with the question I was faced with: “Should I take the ACT or SAT if I am bad at standardized tests?,” I cannot give you a clear answer without generalizing the neurodiverse population. However, I can o�er this suggestion: take a practice ACT or SAT and see where you are at and how you compare to your preferred schools’ typical incoming class test scores (these rates are usually readily accessible and published yearly). Using this information, you can

then determine how much work you would need to do to get into your intended schools’ required or desired test score range, so as to help your chances for admission. If the gap between your scores or score potential is such that you can estimate that it would take e�ort away from extracurriculars and grades, then perhaps you might decide not to take it. And so with standardized tests, as in all settings, I strongly encourage all neurodiverse students to advocate for themselves and proactively seek out accommodations available to them and that they may need.
